guide.title: Gentoo HPPA Installation Guide
guide.abstract: Gentoo Linux is installable on an HP PA-RISC machine. The port is in early development, and notes about this document or the install in general, should be addressed to Gentoo's Bugzilla.

section.title: Note about the current state of this port

body.p: As of this writing, the SMP and 64-bit kernels are not well tested. Testing and feedback are very welcome.
The supported hardware only depends on the kernel. You can find a list of supported platforms at the ESIEE web site.

body.note: The boot procedure is briefly described here. If you need more help or alternate ways to boot your HPPA (e.g. via serial line), please read the HOWTO at http://tldp.org/HOWTO/PA-RISC-Linux-Boot-HOWTO/index.html.
body.p: During the boot process, you will see a message similar to the following :
body.pre: Searching for Potential Boot Devices. To terminate search, press and hold the ESCAPE key.
body.p:
When this message appears, press and hold the Esc key until an option menu appears. This can take a while, be patient. By default, you should enter the BOOT_ADMIN console.
On some 715s and 725s, an option menu may appear. You can enter the BOOT_ADMIN console by choosing a) Enter Boot Administration mode and type a<enter>.
Once you have the '>' prompt, you are in BOOT_ADMIN mode.
If you do not know the SCSI ID of your CD-ROM drive, your PA-RISC station will search for it when you issue the search command.
body.pre:
> search
Searching for Devices with Bootable Media. To terminate search, please press and hold the ESCAPE key.
body.p: Your PA-RISC station will now display all the available boot media. This is an example result of this command :
body.pre:
Device Selection Device Path Device Type and Utilities ---------------------------------------------------------------------------
P0 scsi.5.0 TOSHIBA CD-ROM XM-3301TA IPL P1 scsi.2.0 COMPAQ ST32550N IPL P2 lan.0010a7-06d1b6.3.6 server IPL
>
body.p:
Of course, this example will vary depending on your hardware configuration.
Now that you know which device you must boot, let us boot it.
body.pre:
> boot scsi.5.0 ipl
Trying scsi.5.0
body.p: The ipl keywords (Initial Program Loader) tells palo (the PA-RISC boot LOader) to enter interactive mode. This will allow you to change, for example, the kernel boot parameters.

Lifimage is not available now. You can use Debian's lifimage to create a shell but that lifimage does not ship with the bunzip2 utility, which means that you will have to decompress the stages before using them. You will also have to put them on an FTP or HTTP server in order to fetch them with wget at install time. The kernel version of the lifimage must be greater than or equal to 2.4.20 otherwise your system will not work at all

section.title: After booting : Interacting with PALO, the PA-RISC Linux Loader

body.p: When the boot process is successful, palo will start in interactive mode.
body.pre:
Boot path initialized. Attempting to load IPL.
Hard booted. palo ipl 1.2 root@b180l.da-kot Tue Apr 8 12:43:07 CEST 2003
Boot image contains: 0/vmlinux32 4028015 bytes @ 0x1520000 0/ramdisk 834748 bytes @ 0xf800 Current command line: 0/vmlinux initrd=initrd.gz TERM=linux console=tty root=/dev/ram0 init=/linuxrc 0: 0/vmlinux 1: initrd=initrd.gz 2: TERM=linux 3: console=tty 4: root=/dev/ram0 5: init=/linuxrc
Edit which field? (or 'b' to boot with this command line)? 0
body.p:
These parameters are suitable for most situations.
If you need extra features you must add apropriate kewords to the end of the command line. To add a keyword, edit the last field, add a space and type your keyword. The only implemented keyword as of now is cdcache which tells the LiveCD to load itself into RAM, allowing you to unmount the CD.
body.pre: (or 'b' to boot with this command line)? 5 init=/linuxrc cdcache
body.p: Now that you tweaked your kernel boot params, boot it.
body.pre: (or 'b' to boot with this command line)? b

body.p: A quick review of the installation process: You will create partitions, initialise them with filesystems, and then extract either a stage 1, a stage 2 or a stage 3 tarball. If you use a stage 1 or a stage 2 tarball, you will take the necessary steps to get your system to stage 3. Once your system is at stage 3, you can configure it (by tweaking configuration files, installing a bootloader, etc). Once you reboot it you will have a fully-functional Gentoo Linux system. Depending on what stage of the build process you are starting from, here is what is required for installation:

tr.ti: partition/filesystem setup, emerge rsync, bootstrap, emerge system, emerge linux sources, final configuration
partition/filesystem setup, emerge rsync, emerge system, emerge linux sources, final configuration
partition/filesystem setup, emerge rsync (optional), final configuration

body.p: The first step is to insert any needed modules. You may not need to do this since most of the standard PA-RISC hardware drivers are built into the kernel. To view a list of all available network card modules, type ls /lib/modules/*/kernel/drivers/net/*. To load a particular module, type:
body.pre: # modprobe pcnet32 (replace pcnet32 with your NIC module)
body.p: Now, if you want to be able to access any SCSI hardware that was not detected during the PCI auto-detection process, you will need to load the appropriate modules from /lib/modules, again using modprobe:
body.pre: # modprobe aic7xxx # modprobe sr_mod # modprobe sd_mod
body.p: The above example the aic7xxx SCSI driver is loaded, or modprobed and SCSI CD-ROM (sr_mod) and disk (sd_mod) support are loaded.
body.note: hdparm is included on the Gentoo ISO. If any of your drives require tweaking, now would be a good time to do so. On reasonably modern hardware hdparm -d 1 /dev/hdx should be quite safe. You can use hdparm -v /dev/hdx to check your drive's settings, and hdparm -t /dev/hdx to check your drive's performance.

body.p: The Gentoo installation lets you configure a working network, allowing you to use ssh, scp or wget as needed before even beginning the installation process. Even if you do not need to do these things immediately, you should go ahead and set up networking now. Once set up, Portage will be able to use your configured network from inside the chroot environment (required for installing Gentoo Linux).
Network configuration is simple with DHCP. If your ISP does not use DHCP, skip down to the static configuration section below.
body.pre: # dhcpcd eth0
body.note: Some ISPs require you to provide a hostname. To do that, add a -h myhostname flag to the dhcpcd command line above.
body.p: If you receive dhcpConfig warnings, do not panic: The errors are most likely cosmetic. Skip down to Network testing below.

You need to setup just enough networking (to enable you to download sources for the system build) as well as the required localhost interface. Type in the following commands, replacing $IFACE with your network interface (typically eth0), $IPNUM with your IP address, $BCAST with your broadcast address, and $NMASK with your network mask. For the route command, replace $GTWAY with your default gateway.
body.pre: # /sbin/ifconfig $IFACE $IPNUM broadcast $BCAST netmask $NMASK # /sbin/route add -net default gw $GTWAY netmask 0.0.0.0 metric 1
body.p: Now, it is time to create the /etc/resolv.conf file so that name resolution (finding Web/FTP sites by name, rather than just by IP address) will work.
body.note: At the moment the only editor installed by default is nano, a small and very easy-to-use visual editor. Use nano with the -w option to turn off automatic line-wrapping.
body.p: Here is a template to follow for creating your /etc/resolv.conf file:
body.pre: domain mydomain.com nameserver 10.0.0.1 nameserver 10.0.0.2
body.p: Replace 10.0.0.1 and 10.0.0.2 with the IP addresses of your primary and secondary DNS servers respectively.
If you are behind a proxy, it is necessary to configure your proxy before you continue. You will need to export some variables to set up the proxy accordingly.
body.pre: # export http_proxy="machine.company.com:1234" # export ftp_proxy="$http_proxy" # export RSYNC_PROXY="$http_proxy"

body.p: Now that your network has been configured, the /sbin/ifconfig -a command should show (hopefully!) that your network card is working (look for UP and RUNNING in the output).
body.pre: eth0 Link encap:Ethernet HWaddr 00:50:BA:8F:61:7A inet addr:192.168.0.2 Bcast:192.168.0.255 Mask:255.255.255.0 inet6 addr: fe80::50:ba8f:617a/10 Scope:Link UP BROADCAST RUNNING MULTICAST MTU:1500 Metric:1 RX packets:1498792 errors:0 dropped:0 overruns:0 frame:0 TX packets:1284980 errors:0 dropped:0 overruns:0 carrier:0 collisions:1984 txqueuelen:100 RX bytes:485691215 (463.1 Mb) TX bytes:123951388 (118.2 Mb) Interrupt:11

body.p: Networking should now be configured and usable. You should be able to use the included ssh, scp and wget commands to connect to other machines on your LAN or the Internet.

chapter.title: Set up partitions and building the system

body.note: At this point, if you need more than one console, do not forget to set a password for root. Additionally, many programs are available on the LiveCD, such as screen, lynx, and irssi

body.p: Run fdisk to create the partitions you want.
body.pre: # fdisk /dev/sdX replace sdX by the disk on which you want to create a partition. (i.e. sda, hda, ...)
body.warn: PALO needs a special partition to work. You have to create a partition of at least 16 MB at the begining of your disk. This partition must be of type FO (Linux/PA-RISC boot)
body.impo: If your disk is larger than 2 GB, you will need to create a boot partition in the first 2 GB of your disk. PALO is unable to read a kernel after the 2 GB limit.
body.p: After you have succefully created your partitions and placed filesystems on them, you are ready to begin the fun stuff. In the following example, the root partition is at /dev/sda3, the swap partition at /dev/sda4 for a stage 1 installation (The stage 1 tarball is fetched from the gentoo mirrors).
body.pre: # swapon /dev/sda4 # mount -n /dev/sda3 /mnt/gentoo
body.note: After mounting your new root partition to /mnt/gentoo, it is time to mount any other partitions (e.g. /boot, /usr, /var).
body.pre: # cd /mnt/gentoo # wget http://www.ibiblio.org/pub/Linux/distributions/gentoo/experimental/hppa/stages/stage1-hppa1.1-1.4_pre20040403.tar.bz2 # tar xpjvf stage1-hppa1.1-1.4_pre20030403.tar.bz2 # cp /etc/resolv.conf etc/resolv.conf # mount -o bind /proc proc # chroot . Now you are in your new system # env-update This will correctly set your evironment variables # source /etc/profile # nano -w /etc/make.conf Tweak your optimisations and mirrors here # emerge sync This will retrieve the current portage tree which is about 10 MB
body.p: If you started from a stage 1, start the bootstrap process.
body.pre: cd /usr/portage ./scripts/bootstrap.sh
body.p: This brings you to stage 2, where you will now compile and install the base system files.
body.pre: export CONFIG_PROTECT="-*" emerge system
body.p: Your Gentoo setup is now at stage 3. If you start from a stage 3, it is possible that there are some new and/or updated packages. To update them:
body.pre: unset CONFIG_PROTECT emerge -uD world
body.p: The base system is now up to date.

section.title: Getting current kernel sources for HP-PA

body.p: There is a specially patched kernel tuned for HP-PA machines available in Gentoo Linux. To install it just emerge hppa-sources
body.pre: # emerge hppa-sources
body.p: Now you may need to patch your kernel to add certains support like for SGI's XFS filesystem, Usagi IPv6, etc. None of those patches are currently tested, so do so at your own risk. Once the sources have been fetched and unpacked, you will need to configure your kernel.

section.title: Configuring and compiling your kernel
section.body:
Here is how to configure and compile your kernel.
# cd /usr/src/linux # make menuconfig # make vmlinux modules modules_install # cp vmlinux System.map /boot
In order to have a working kernel, you will have to choose the right options in your configuration. Some of them should be enabled staticaly and not compiled as modules. You will need to enable the "Code maturity level options --> Prompt for development and/or incomplete code/drivers" option to see several of these selections. Under the "File systems" section, be sure to enable the Device File System (note that you do not need to enable the "/dev/pts file system support" option). You will also need to enable the Virtual Memory File system. If you have a HIL mouse or keyboard, do not forget to compile in support for them. For this, you must enable the "Keyboard support", the "Mouse support" and the "Event interface support" in the section "Input core support".
In the section "HIL support", if you have no mouse on your HIL port, it is recommend to use only the "HIL Keyboard (basic) support".
By the way, full support is available when choosing the options "HP System Device Controller i8042 Support" and then "HIL MLC Support", "HIL Keyboard (full) support" and "HIL Mouse & Pointer support". But in this case DO NOT select the "HIL Keyboard (basic) support".

body.p: On the PA-RISC platform, the boot loader is called palo. You can find the configuration file in /etc/palo.conf. Here is a sample configuration :
body.pre: --commandline=2/vmlinux root=/dev/sdb2 HOME=/ --recoverykernel=/vmlinux.old --init-partitioned=/dev/sdb
body.p:
The first line tells palo the location of the kernel and which boot parameters it must use. 2/vmlinux means the kernel named /vmlinux resides on the second partition. The path to the kernel is relative to the root of the partition, not to the root of your file tree. The second line indicates which recovery kernel to use. If it is your first install and you do not have a recovery kernel, please comment this out.
The third line indicates on which disk palo will reside. When configuration is done, just run palo.
body.pre: # palo

body.note: It is extremely important that this step is completed. Major clock drift will be experienced if you do not set localtime correctly.
body.p: At this point, you should have a stage 3 system that is ready for final configuration. You will start this process by setting the time zone. By setting the timezone before building the kernel you ensure that users get reasonable uname -a output.
Look for your timezone (or UTC if you prefer to use Universal Time Constant) in /usr/share/zoneinfo. Then, make a symbolic link by typing:
body.pre: # ln -sf /usr/share/zoneinfo/path/to/timezonefile /etc/localtime
body.p: You might also want to check /etc/rc.conf to make sure your time zone settings are correct.

Now you need to choose a system logger to install. Gentoo Linux offers sysklogd, which is the traditional set of system logging daemons. Also available are: msyslog, syslog-ng, and metalog. Power users seem to gravitate away from sysklogd (not very good performance), toward the newer alternatives. In paticular, metalog seems to be quite popular. To merge your logger of choice, type one of the next four sets of commands:
body.pre: # emerge app-admin/sysklogd # rc-update add sysklogd default or # emerge app-admin/syslog-ng # rc-update add syslog-ng default or # emerge app-admin/metalog # rc-update add metalog default or # emerge app-admin/msyslog # rc-update add msyslog default
body.warn: In the case of syslog-ng you need to create /etc/syslog-ng/syslog-ng.conf. See /etc/syslog-ng for a sample configuration file.
body.impo: Metalog flushes its output to the disk in blocks, so messages are not immediately recorded into the system logs. If you are trying to debug a daemon, this performance-enhancing behavior is less than helpful. When your Gentoo Linux system is up and running, you can send metalog a USR1 signal to temporarily turn off this message buffering (meaning that tail -f /var/log/everything/current will now work in real time, as expected), and a USR2 signal to turn buffering back on again.
body.p: Now, you may optionally choose a cron package to use. The current available choices in Gentoo Linux are: dcron, fcron, and vcron. If you do not know which one to choose, you might as well grab vcron. Again, please issue one of the following sets of commands:
body.pre: # emerge sys-apps/dcron # crontab /etc/crontab or # emerge sys-apps/fcron # crontab /etc/crontab or # emerge sys-apps/vcron do not forget to add your *cron to the proper init level. # rc-update add *cron default
body.p: For more information how how cron works under Gentoo Linux, see this announcement.
For more information on starting programs and daemons at startup, see the rc-script guide.

Your Gentoo Linux system is almost ready for use. All you need to do now is configure a few important system files and install the PALO boot loader. The first file you need to configure is /etc/fstab. Remember that you should use the notail option for your boot partition if you chose to create a ReiserFS filesystem on it. Remember to specify ext2, ext3 or reiserfs filesystem types as appropriate.
Your /etc/fstab should somewhat resemble the one shown below, but of course be sure to replace "BOOT", "ROOT" and "SWAP" with the actual block devices you are using (such as hda1, etc.)
body.pre:
# /etc/fstab: static file system information. # # noatime turns off atimes for increased performance (atimes normally aren't # needed; notail increases performance of ReiserFS (at the expense of storage # efficiency). it is safe to drop the noatime options if you want and to # switch between notail and tail freely.
# <fs> <mountpoint> <type> <opts> <dump/pass>
# NOTE: If your BOOT partition is ReiserFS, add the notail option to opts.
/dev/BOOT /boot ext2 noauto,noatime 1 2 /dev/ROOT / ext3 noatime 0 1 /dev/SWAP none swap sw 0 0 /dev/cdroms/cdrom0 /mnt/cdrom iso9660 noauto,ro 0 0 proc /proc proc defaults 0 0
body.warn: Please notice that /boot is NOT mounted at boot time. This is to protect the data in /boot from corruption. If you need to access /boot, please mount it!

body.p: Before you forget, set the root password by typing:
body.pre: # passwd

body.p:
Edit this file so that it contains your fully-qualified domain name on a single line, i.e. mymachine.mydomain.com.
# echo mymachine.mydomain.com > /etc/hostname

This file contains a list of IP addresses and their associated hostnames. it is used by the system to resolve the IP addresses of any hostnames that may not be in your nameservers. Here is a template for this file:
body.pre: 127.0.0.1 localhost # the next line contains your IP for your local LAN, and your associated machine name 192.168.1.1 mymachine.mydomain.com mymachine
body.note: If you are on a DHCP network, it might be helpful to set localhost to your machine's actual hostname. This will help GNOME and many other programs in name resolution.

body.p: Add the names of any modules that are necessary for the proper functioning of your system to the /etc/modules.autoload file (you can also add any options you need to the same line.) When Gentoo Linux boots, these modules will be automatically loaded. Of particular importance is your ethernet card module, if you happened to compile it as a module:
body.pre: 3c59x
body.p: Edit the /etc/conf.d/net script to get your network configured for your first boot:
body.pre: # nano -w /etc/conf.d/net # rc-update add net.eth0 default
body.p: If you have multiple network cards you need to create additional net.ethx scripts for each one (x = 1, 2, ...):
body.pre: # cd /etc/init.d # cp net.eth0 net.ethx # rc-update add net.ethx default

section.title: Configure basic settings (including the international keymap setting)

body.pre: # nano -w /etc/rc.conf
body.p: Follow the directions in the file to configure the basic settings. Please make sure that CLOCK is set to your liking. International keyboard users will want to set the KEYMAP variable (browse /usr/share/keymaps to see the various available keymaps).

Congratulations! You have just completed your install of Gentoo Linux on your HPPA station. We welcome any comments or suggestions that you may have to help us better our HPPA port. Thank you for taking the time to install.
You are now at the point where you can do one of a few things. Either unmount everything and reboot to start installing ebuilds or you can start installing them now.
body.note: A large part of this installation document was based on the Gentoo SPARC Installation Guide and from the PA-RISC-Linux-Boot-HOWTO.
